CreditLine: Promised gift of John and Berthe Ford
Description: Embracing his Wisdom, the fearsome Raktayamari, the "red enemy-of-death" (also known as the red Yamantaka), stands for total enlightenment. The buffalo he tramples is a symbol of the death he overcomes. He carries a staff and a skull cup, and his Wisdom holds a skull cup and a chopper. The figures across the top represent the lineage of the teaching, taught in secret for generations: five mahasiddhas, then four conversing monks, of whom the first is Indian and the rest Tibetans of the Sakya order.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection
Exhibitions.Textblock: Desire and Devotion: Art from India, Nepal, and Tibet in the John and Berthe Ford Collection. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; Santa Barbara Museum of Art, Santa Barbara; Albuquerque Museum, Albuquerque; Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham. 2001-2003.

Provenance: Gautam Rana, Kathmandu, Nepal [date and mode of acquisition unknown]; John and Berthe Ford, Baltimore, November 1998, by purchase.
Title: The Identification Deity Raktayamari
